titleStmt.title: Variants of imperative of final-weak verbs (2sg.m in a pattern)
titleStmt.author: Veronika Engler

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for imperative of final-weak verbs (2sg.m in a pattern) - ex. CCī / ʔvCvC and then give example

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found

wib:featureValueObservation.note: In pausal position -ei, (ʕlei)
Pickett (2005:244) notes that in the imperative of finally weak verbs: "The m.s. form is characterised by a final vowel in these dialects as in imši (go!), etc."
Pickett (2005:244) notes that in the imperative of finally weak verbs: "The m.s. form is characterised by a final vowel in these dialects as in imši (go!), etc."
Pickett (2005:244) notes that in the imperative of finally weak verbs: "The m.s. form is characterised by a final vowel in these dialects as in imši (go!), etc."
Pickett (2005:244) notes that in the imperative of finally weak verbs: "The m.s. form is characterised by a final vowel in these dialects as in imši (go!), etc."
Pickett (2005:244) notes that in the imperative of finally weak verbs: "The m.s. form is characterised by a final vowel in these dialects as in imši (go!), etc."
Pickett (2005:244) notes that in the imperative of finally weak verbs: "The m.s. form is characterised by a final vowel in these dialects as in imši (go!), etc."
The verb has the form ṭawa - īṭwi (CaCa - īCCi)
The verb has the form nəsa - yənsa
The verb has the form bəča - yəbči
The verb has the form bəča - yəbči
The verb has the form kara - yikri
The verb has the form nisi - yinsa
The verb has the form miša - yimši
The verb has the form buqa - yibqa
ʔubqa is also attested, but seems to be rare
The verb has the form nisi - yinsa
The verb has the form bana - yibna
Forms with an inital vowel are attested, e.g. əqrā
nsā is also attested
Forms with an inital vowel are attested, e.g. ənsī
The verb has the form məši - īmši (CəCi -īCCi)
The verb has the form baqa - ibqā (CaCa -īCCa)
The verb has the form nəsi - īnsā (CəCi -īCCa)
This structure relates to the i-stem of the third weak radical verbs
This structure relates to the a-stem of the third weak radical verbs
This form is typical of all eastern Arabian dialects and is of the ʕAnazi pattern(Johnstone 1967:50, 112).
